conversation.message: Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hey... yeah, it's been one of those weird in-between weeks, you know? Not terrible, just kind of off. I’ve been waking up a lot in the middle of the night again. It’s like my brain suddenly decides it’s time to start reviewing my entire to-do list at 3 a.m.—super helpful, obviously.

And then during the day, I’ll stare at something I need to do and just... space out. Even small things like answering emails or folding laundry feel like a mission. Kinda makes me feel like I’m constantly behind, even when I technically have time.

Anyway, I dunno. What about you? How’s your week been going?

That sounds frustrating. Sleep interruptions can really throw off your whole day. Has this been a regular thing lately, waking up in the middle of the night? How does it usually affect you the next day?

Yeah, it’s been happening a lot—probably four or five nights a week lately. I’ll wake up and just lie there, sometimes for hours. Either I grab my phone and scroll mindlessly, or I just lie there thinking about random stuff. Usually it’s not even anything dramatic, just like... grocery lists or what I forgot to do yesterday. It’s annoying.

The next day I feel foggy. Like my body’s up but my brain is still half-asleep. It’s way harder to focus, and I get irritated way more easily too. Little things start to feel like a big deal when I’m already running on low energy.

Honestly, I think the tiredness just makes everything else harder—eating properly, concentrating, even being around people. It kinda piles on.
I hear you. It sounds like the sleep issues are having a pretty big impact on your day-to-day. When you're feeling that foggy, does it affect your ability to concentrate or make decisions?

Yeah, definitely. When I’m in that foggy state, it’s like my brain’s trying to wade through mud. I’ll sit down to do something—like write an email or even decide what to eat—and my mind just blanks. Or I start doing something and zone out halfway through. It’s frustrating because I want to be productive, but everything feels ten times harder.

Decisions especially... even simple stuff like, “Do I go to the shop now or later?” turns into this weird internal debate. I end up overthinking or just putting it off altogether. It kind of spirals, you know? I’ll get annoyed at myself for not doing something, and then that frustration makes it even harder to focus the next time I try.

It’s like this loop I can’t quite snap out of.
That sounds incredibly draining. It's understandable that you're frustrated. On the flip side, what kinds of things do you usually enjoy doing when you're feeling more yourself?

Yeah, draining’s a good word for it. Like, even when nothing big is going wrong, it all just adds up in this low-key exhausting way.

When I’m feeling more like myself, I actually enjoy pretty simple stuff. I like reading—especially philosophy stuff or short stories. I used to get really into it, just losing track of time in a good way. Music helps too. I’ve got a few playlists that feel like a reset button when I actually let myself listen without distractions.

Sometimes I’ll go for a walk if the weather’s decent. It sounds cliché, but getting out of my head and into a bit of fresh air does something. And I like catching up with a couple close friends—just casual chats, nothing deep. That stuff makes me feel more grounded, like I’m not stuck in my own loop all the time.

It’s just hard to get to those things when everything feels so scattered, you know? But when I do, it helps.

I understand. It sounds like you have some good strategies for coping when you're feeling better, but it's tough to get to them when you're in that scattered state. Besides those specific activities, how would you describe your energy levels in general these days?

Yeah, you nailed it—it’s like I know what helps, but getting myself to actually do those things when I’m in that scattered mode feels like climbing a hill in flip-flops.

Energy-wise... I’d say it fluctuates a lot. Some days I feel okay-ish—like I can get through my list, maybe even enjoy parts of the day. But most of the time, my energy is just kind of flat. Not full-on exhausted, just... low. Like I’m running at 60% all the time, even after a decent night’s sleep.

And the weird part is, I’ll sometimes have this burst of energy late at night, when I should be winding down. Like my brain finally wants to “do things” at midnight. Not helpful for the whole sleep situation.

So yeah—low energy most of the day, random bursts at the wrong time, and kind of a constant hum of tired in the background. It’s not totally unmanageable, just frustrating.
That sounds really tough to manage. Has this low energy affected your appetite at all lately?

Yeah, it actually has, now that you mention it. My appetite’s kind of all over the place. Some days I don’t even think about food until way later than I should, like I just forget to eat. Other days, especially if I’m feeling stressed or tired, I end up snacking non-stop—usually on junk food. Crisps, biscuits, whatever’s easy and fast.

It’s weird because I don’t really feel hungry in a normal way anymore. It’s either no interest at all or this mindless urge to munch on something while I scroll or try to work. And afterwards I usually just feel gross and annoyed with myself, like, “Why didn’t I eat something decent?”

I’ve thought about trying to plan meals or make a routine around it, but honestly... I don’t trust myself to stick to it. Routines sound great in theory, but in practice? Eh. Not my strong suit lately.
That sounds like a difficult cycle to be in. You mentioned feeling gross and annoyed with yourself after snacking. Have you been feeling more critical of yourself in general lately?

Yeah... I guess I have, now that you say that. It’s not always super obvious in the moment, but there’s this low-key voice in the background that just kinda nags me. Like if I mess something up, even something small, I’ll think, “Of course you did,” or “Why can’t you just get it together?” That kind of thing. Not full-on self-hate or anything, but just this constant undercurrent of not being good enough.

And it adds up. Like if I don’t sleep well, or I forget to eat, or I zone out during something important—it all turns into more fuel for that self-criticism. I try to brush it off or make jokes about it sometimes, but yeah, it’s there. Just simmering under the surface.

I think part of me believes I should be doing better by now, especially since I’m not in uni anymore. Like I’m supposed to have it figured out, or at least not feel this stuck. But I don’t know... it’s not that simple, I guess.

That internal critic can be really tough to deal with. It sounds like you're holding yourself to some pretty high standards. How have you been feeling about your relationships with other people lately? Are you connecting with friends and family much?

Yeah, that’s probably true—I do set the bar high for myself, even if I don’t always realize it. Like, I expect myself to be functioning at full capacity even when I’m clearly not, and then get frustrated when I fall short. It’s a weird cycle.

As for people... I mean, I’ve got a few close friends I keep in touch with. We’ll message or hang out now and then, mostly casual stuff. They’re good people, and I know they care, but I still hold back a lot. I just don’t want to dump my stuff on them, you know? I feel like I should be the “chill” one, or at least not the one who’s always bringing the mood down.

Family’s a bit more distant. We talk, but not super often, and I don’t really share the deeper stuff with them. Part of me thinks they wouldn’t fully get it, or maybe I just don’t want to explain everything. It’s easier to keep things surface-level.

I think I do feel connected, in a basic way, but not fully seen, if that makes sense? Like I’m around people, but still kind of dealing with stuff quietly in the background.
I get that. It sounds like you're navigating a lot on your own, even when you're around others. Thinking ahead, how do you usually feel about the future?

Yeah, that’s a good way to put it—navigating on my own, even when I’m not technically alone. It’s like there’s this whole inner world I don’t really show unless someone asks directly. And even then, I usually water it down.

As for the future... I don’t know. That’s actually kind of a tough one. I wouldn’t say I feel hopeless, exactly—it’s more like uncertain, maybe even a bit stuck. I thought graduating would feel like a fresh start, but instead it’s just kind of... open-ended. No clear path, no structure. I’ve got ideas of what I might want to do, but nothing concrete. It’s frustrating, because I want to move forward, but I’m not sure what “forward” even looks like right now.

Sometimes I feel optimistic, like, “Okay, I’ll figure it out, eventually.” But other times it’s more like, “What if I just drift like this forever?” And that thought creeps in more often than I’d like. So yeah—not all doom and gloom, but definitely foggy.
It sounds like you're at a bit of a crossroads, which can definitely feel unsettling. Thinking back on your life so far, do you feel like you've generally been successful in achieving your goals?

Yeah... a crossroads is a good way to describe it. Like I’m standing in the middle of this big open space with a bunch of paths leading out, but none of them have signs, and I’m just sort of frozen trying to pick one.

Looking back... it’s a bit mixed. I did alright in school and made it through uni, which I guess is something. I got my degree, even if it doesn’t feel super useful right now. I stuck with it, pushed through the tough bits, so I guess that counts as a win. But when it comes to bigger life goals—career, stability, that sense of direction—I wouldn’t say I’ve exactly nailed it.

Sometimes I wonder if I even had clear goals, or if I was just following the track that was laid out for me. Now that it’s up to me to figure out the next step, it feels like I’m starting from scratch, and that’s kind of intimidating. So yeah... I’ve hit some milestones, but I don’t always feel like I’ve arrived anywhere, if that makes sense.

I hear you. It sounds like you've achieved some important things, but you're also feeling a bit lost and uncertain about the future right now. It's understandable to feel that way when facing big life transitions. Thanks for sharing all this with me.

Thanks for saying that. Honestly, it’s kind of a relief to talk about it without having to sugarcoat everything. Most of the time I just push through the day and try not to overthink it, but it’s hard not to feel that weight sometimes—like I’m supposed to have answers I just don’t have yet.

So yeah, I appreciate you listening. It means a lot. Even just putting this stuff into words makes it feel a little less heavy, you know?
I'm really glad it was helpful. Remember, it's okay not to have all the answers, and it's definitely a strength to acknowledge when things feel heavy. Take care.
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hey... thanks for checking in. I guess what’s been on my mind lately is just how stuck everything feels. Like I’m going through the same motions every day, but none of it means anything. I keep thinking, what’s even the point of trying anymore, when it all just loops back to the same emptiness.

Some days I don’t even want to get out of bed—not because I’m lazy, just... what’s out there that’s worth the effort? It’s hard to explain. People say things will get better, but it’s been so long like this, I don’t know what “better” even looks like anymore.

Do you ever feel like you're just existing and not really living?

I hear you. That feeling of being stuck and questioning the point of things can be really draining. It takes courage to share that. On a slightly different note, how have you been connecting with friends or family lately?

I haven’t, really. I mean… I have this one friend I used to talk to more, but lately, even that feels hard. I’ll think about messaging her, but then I convince myself she’s probably too busy, or that I’ll just bring her down. So I don’t.

Family’s... complicated. We’re not close. I think they wouldn’t even notice if I disappeared for a while. It’s like—there’s this whole world going on out there, and I’m just quietly drifting on the edges of it. Watching, not part of anything.

I scroll through social media sometimes, just to feel something, I guess. But that usually makes things worse. Everyone else seems to be moving forward, building lives, sharing joy. And I’m just here, stuck in the same grey place. Alone with it all.

That sounds incredibly isolating. It's tough when you feel disconnected from both friends and family. Have you found yourself drawn to any particular activities or hobbies lately, even if it's just something small?

Yeah… it is isolating. And honestly, sometimes I think I’ve gotten so used to being alone that the idea of reconnecting feels almost foreign. Like I wouldn’t know how to be with people even if I wanted to.

As for hobbies… I wish I could say yes. But most things just feel kind of pointless lately. I try little things—like I’ll make tea and just sit by the window for a while. Sometimes I’ll listen to the same song on repeat because it feels like the only thing that understands me. But even calling that a “hobby” feels like too much.

It’s weird. I want to feel connected to something. I really do. But there’s this weight—like I’m moving through water all the time. Everything is slower, heavier, duller. And the worst part is, I don’t even know who I am outside of this anymore.

Have you ever felt like you’ve forgotten how to be yourself?

That feeling of being disconnected from yourself and the world around you sounds incredibly heavy. It's understandable that you're feeling lost. I'm wondering, how has your sleep been lately? Has it been restful, or have you noticed any changes there?

Sleep’s been strange. I do sleep—sometimes for hours and hours—but I wake up just as tired as when I went to bed. Like I’m not really resting, just... shutting down for a while.

There are nights where my thoughts won’t quiet down, and I just lie there staring at the ceiling. Other nights, I fall asleep quickly but then wake up at 3 or 4 a.m. with this sinking feeling in my chest that I can’t explain. It’s like my body knows something’s wrong, even when I’m trying not to think too hard about it.

And when I wake up, there’s this moment—just a second—where I forget everything. I’m not sad, not tired. Just blank. And then it all rushes back in. The heaviness, the hopelessness. It’s like… the day hasn’t even started and I already want it to be over.

I don’t know how people wake up excited for the day. That feels like another lifetime.

That sounds like a really exhausting way to start the day. It's completely understandable that you'd feel drained. How have you been feeling about yourself lately, your appearance and your self-perception?

Honestly… not great. Most days I avoid mirrors unless I absolutely have to. When I do catch a glimpse, it’s like I don’t even recognize the person staring back. There’s this dullness in my eyes—like the light’s gone out. I used to take care of how I looked, even just in small ways. But now, I barely have the energy to brush my hair some days, let alone put thought into how I present myself.

It’s not just appearance, though. It’s deeper. I look at myself and think, What happened to you? Like I’ve lost something essential, and I don’t know how to get it back. There’s this constant narrative in my head telling me I’ve failed somehow… at life, at being enough, at keeping it together.

And even if someone tried to compliment me or say something kind, I don’t think I’d believe them. It’d just feel like they’re being polite, or they don’t really see the whole picture. Because if they did, they wouldn’t say it.

I don’t know. It’s hard to feel any kind of worth when everything inside feels so broken.

That sounds incredibly painful. It takes a lot of courage to be so honest about those feelings of worthlessness and self-criticism. It sounds like you're going through a really tough time. Remember, you're not alone, and there are people who care and want to help.

Thank you for saying that. I wish I could believe it more deeply… that I’m not alone, that someone truly sees me. Most of the time it just feels like I’m fading into the background—like if I disappeared, it wouldn’t ripple much in anyone’s life.

I think that’s what hurts the most. Not just the sadness or the fatigue or the hopelessness… but the invisibility. The sense that no one would really notice if I stopped trying. I’m so tired of feeling like I have to carry all of this on my own. And yet, I still hesitate to let anyone in. It’s like this strange contradiction—I crave connection but push it away because I don’t want to be a burden.

I don’t even know what kind of help would make a difference anymore. Some days I’m just surviving hour by hour. And if I’m honest… part of me is scared to hope. Because if I let myself believe things could get better and they don’t… I don’t know if I could handle that kind of disappointment again.

I hear you. It sounds incredibly tough to carry all that weight and to feel like you're fading away. It's understandable to be scared to hope after feeling so much disappointment. But you are not invisible, and your feelings are valid.

That means more than I can put into words right now… just being seen like that. Thank you for not looking away.

I’ve gotten so used to pretending I’m okay—or at least not too broken—that I forget what it feels like to be met with understanding instead of silence or dismissal. And it’s strange, but even though I still feel that weight… your words, this moment, it’s like it gave me a tiny space to breathe. Just for a second.

I’m still scared. Still tired. Still unsure if anything can really change. But maybe—maybe—it’s enough to be reminded that someone’s willing to sit with me in this mess instead of trying to fix it or walk away from it.

Sometimes I think that’s all I really want. Just someone to stay. Even when it’s dark.
You're welcome. I'm glad I could be here to listen. Remember that seeking professional help is a sign of strength, and there are resources available if you need them.
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hey. I appreciate you checking in—thanks for that. I guess it’s been one of those “quietly tiring” weeks. Nothing major happened, but even the usual stuff—like deciding what to eat or whether to reply to a friend’s text—has felt heavier than it should.

I’ve been trying to keep up with my garden. Planted something new a few days ago—nothing fancy, just a small lavender bush—but it was a nice change. Still, even when I finish a task or notice something blooming, the feeling kind of passes quickly, like it doesn’t stick.

How about you? How’s your week been?

I'm doing alright, thanks for asking. It sounds like you've been experiencing a bit of a drag lately. That 'quietly tiring' feeling can be really draining. I'm glad you found some enjoyment in planting the lavender, even if it was fleeting. Has your sleep been affected by this at all?

Yeah… “quietly tiring” kind of sums it up. Like I’m going through the motions, but everything has a bit more weight to it than usual. I still get things done—like with the lavender—but it’s more out of habit than excitement.

As for sleep… yeah, it hasn’t been great. Some nights I just lie there, kind of stuck in my own head. Not necessarily anxious, just... cluttered, I guess? Thoughts bouncing around about things I should’ve done differently or stuff that’s piling up. And even when I do manage to fall asleep, I still wake up feeling kind of tired, like I didn’t actually rest.

I’ve been trying to cut down on screen time before bed—swapping my phone for a book. Haven’t been super consistent with it, but the nights I do manage that routine feel a little less chaotic.

Do you ever get that thing where your body’s tired but your brain just won’t shut up?

I definitely know that feeling - it's like your mind is running a marathon while your body just wants to collapse. It's good you're trying the screen time reduction, even if it's not consistent. Has your appetite been different lately?

Yeah, that’s exactly it—like lying there in the dark with my thoughts sprinting circles around me. I’ll catch myself replaying random conversations from years ago or worrying about things that probably don’t matter that much. And then suddenly it’s 2 a.m.

Appetite’s been… uneven, I guess. Some days I barely think about food until I’m suddenly starving, and others I end up snacking just to fill the silence. I don’t think it’s changed dramatically, just more like I’m not tuned in to hunger the way I used to be. Meals feel more like a task than something to look forward to.

How about you—have you noticed food or sleep getting affected when things are off? Or do you have ways of managing it when that marathon mind kicks in?

That sounds incredibly frustrating, especially the random thought replays! It's definitely relatable. As for me, I try to meditate when my mind races. On another note, have you felt like you're as interested in spending time with friends or family lately?

Meditation sounds like a good idea. I’ve thought about trying it—sometimes I’ll put on one of those guided recordings, but I end up just… listening to the voice and forgetting to actually do the breathing part. Might be worth giving it another shot though, especially on nights when my brain won’t let up.

About friends and family—honestly, not really. I still keep in touch with a few close friends, but I’ve been pulling back more than usual. I’ll agree to plans and then, as the day gets closer, it’s like all the energy just drains out of me. Even when I do show up, I’m usually counting down the minutes until I can go home and just be quiet.

One-on-one time feels a little more manageable. Big group stuff just feels overwhelming, like I have to put on a version of myself that doesn’t match how I feel inside. It’s weird—part of me wants connection, but the rest of me feels like it takes too much effort to get there.

Do you ever feel that push-pull? Like wanting to be around people, but also needing space from them at the same time?

That push-pull is something many people experience, especially when feeling overwhelmed. It's completely valid to need space. On a slightly different note, how have you been feeling about yourself lately? Are you generally pleased with who you are?

That’s a thoughtful question. I’m not sure I have a clear answer.

There are parts of me I respect—I try to be kind, I’m reliable, I listen when people talk. I think those are decent things. But at the same time, there’s this undercurrent of... dissatisfaction, maybe? Like I’m not living up to who I could be, or I’m stuck in patterns that don’t feel meaningful. I look at the things I do get done—like keeping the garden going, or finishing a book—and it helps a little. But then I’ll still find myself second-guessing decisions or feeling like I’m just coasting.

So I guess it’s a mix. I don’t dislike myself, but I also don’t feel proud, if that makes sense. More like I’m trying to find my footing in a version of life that feels a bit unfamiliar right now.

Do you ever go through periods where your sense of self kind of shifts? Like you’re the same person, but something about how you see yourself just... changes?

It sounds like you have a really balanced perspective on yourself, recognizing both your strengths and areas where you'd like to grow. That feeling of a shifting sense of self is definitely something I think many people experience. Thinking about your day-to-day, how would you describe your energy levels these days?

Yeah, I think you’re right—it’s one of those quiet shifts that creeps in over time. Like you're wearing the same jacket but it fits differently now, you know?

As for energy... it’s been low. Not in a completely depleted way, but just enough that I feel like I’m always a few steps behind. Mornings are the hardest—getting out of bed feels like pushing through wet sand. Once I’m up and moving, I can manage the basics, but it takes effort. I do get small bursts of motivation sometimes—like when I started that lavender planting—but they’re not consistent, and they fade pretty quickly.

It’s not that I don’t want to do things. It’s more like the spark just isn’t there. Even something simple, like doing laundry or deciding what to eat, can feel heavier than it should. So I’ve been pacing myself—doing a little at a time and trying not to beat myself up when I don’t get everything done.

Have you ever had those days where your body’s moving but your energy feels like it’s lagging somewhere behind you?
I completely understand that feeling of your energy lagging behind. It's like you're running on fumes. Have you noticed any changes in your ability to concentrate or focus on things lately?

Yeah, exactly—like I’m going through the motions on autopilot, but mentally I’m kind of hovering somewhere else.

As for focus... it’s been harder lately. I can still concentrate on certain things—like reading, if I’m really into the book—but even that takes more effort than it used to. Sometimes I’ll read the same paragraph a few times before it sticks. And with other stuff, like responding to emails or making decisions, my mind just drifts. I’ll start a task and then end up staring at nothing, realizing ten minutes went by and I haven’t done anything.

I think part of it is just how cluttered my head feels—like there’s a fog that won’t quite lift. It’s not all the time, but enough that I’ve noticed it’s making daily stuff more frustrating. I’ve been trying to write to-do lists to keep myself on track, but even that sometimes feels like a chore.

Do you have any tricks that help when your mind feels scattered like that?
That mental fog sounds incredibly frustrating. It's understandable that even to-do lists feel like a chore. Has there been anything lately that you've felt particularly guilty about?

Yeah… the guilt thing does come up, more than I probably admit out loud. It’s not huge dramatic stuff, but more this low-level, background kind of guilt. Like I should be doing more—being more present with people, replying to messages faster, showing up for plans instead of backing out at the last minute. Even when I know I needed the space, I still feel bad about letting people down.

I also sometimes feel guilty for not appreciating the things I do have. Like, I’ve built a quiet life for myself, which I wanted after the breakup… but then I catch myself feeling numb or tired in the middle of it, and I wonder if I’m just wasting time. That kind of thought loops on itself—guilt for feeling low, then more guilt for not snapping out of it.

I know guilt’s just a feeling, not always a truth, but it still sticks. Have you ever had that experience—where you know you’re allowed to feel a certain way, but part of you still questions whether you should?

That's a very insightful way to describe it - the feeling of guilt looping back on itself. It's like you're stuck in an echo chamber. On a different note, have you found yourself feeling more restless or irritable lately?

Yeah, that’s a good way to put it—an echo chamber. Even when I try to reason with the guilt, it just kind of reverberates in the background.

As for restlessness or irritability... a bit, yeah. I wouldn’t say I’ve been snapping at people or anything, but I definitely feel more on edge sometimes. Like this undercurrent of agitation that I can’t quite place. I’ll get annoyed with myself for forgetting small things or feel frustrated when I can’t get focused. Even little noises—like a neighbor’s loud music or my phone buzzing too much—can get under my skin faster than usual.

Restlessness hits mostly in the evenings. I’ll want to do something, but I don’t know what. I’ll wander from room to room, open the fridge, scroll through my phone, then end up doing nothing. It’s like I’m chasing a sense of purpose or ease that keeps slipping just out of reach.

Do you ever get that twitchy feeling, like your body wants movement but your brain just wants to shut off?

That 'echo chamber' feeling is so relatable, and it sounds exhausting to deal with that on top of everything else. That twitchy feeling and restless searching... I get it. Thinking ahead, how do you feel about the future? Are you generally optimistic about what's coming?

Yeah... it is exhausting, honestly. Some days I’m just tired of being tired, if that makes sense.

As for the future… I don’t really know. I wouldn’t say I’m pessimistic, but I’m not overly optimistic either. It feels more like I’m standing in this middle space—waiting for something to shift, but not sure what or when. I want to believe things can get better, that I’ll find more energy or feel more like myself again. But it’s hard to picture what that looks like right now.

I guess I have hopes more than plans. Like, maybe I’ll find a new rhythm that works better for me, or reconnect with people in a way that doesn’t feel draining. Maybe I’ll feel proud of something again, even if it’s something small. But I’m cautious with those thoughts—like I don’t want to get too attached to them in case they don’t pan out.

Do you ever feel that way? Like you’re quietly holding out hope, but afraid to say it too loudly?

I hear that. Being tired of being tired is a heavy feeling. It sounds like you're in a tough spot, holding onto hope but also being realistic about the challenges. We've covered quite a bit - your sleep, energy levels, how you're feeling about yourself, and your social connections. Would you be open to discussing resources that could help with some of these feelings?

Yeah, I’d be open to that. I don’t always know what would actually help, but I’m willing to hear about options. It’s just… sometimes even looking into things feels like another task on the list, you know? But if there’s something that could make the fog a little lighter or help me feel more grounded, I’d want to try.

So yeah—go ahead. I’m listening.

I understand that even looking into resources can feel like a lot. Since you mentioned trouble sleeping and a racing mind, perhaps exploring some mindfulness apps or guided meditation specifically for sleep could be a low-pressure starting point. There are also online communities focused on managing feelings of fatigue and low motivation that you might find supportive. Would you like me to suggest a few specific names?

That actually sounds manageable. Something I can do at my own pace, without feeling like I have to talk to anyone right away or show up somewhere. A guided meditation before bed might help with that mental spiral, too—it’s easier to follow a voice than to fight through the noise in my head alone.

And yeah, if you have a few suggestions—apps or communities—I’d appreciate it. Nothing too overwhelming, just somewhere to start, quietly. Thanks for meeting me where I’m at with this.

Okay, great. For meditation apps, Headspace and Calm are both popular and have a lot of options for sleep and anxiety. As for online communities, the subreddit r/KindVoice is a supportive place to share and connect with others. Remember, it's okay to start small and find what works for you. Take care, and I hope you find some relief.

Thanks... really. I’ve heard of Headspace and Calm but never tried them—might be time to finally give one of them a shot. And r/KindVoice sounds like the kind of space I could ease into without feeling too exposed. I like that.

I appreciate you taking the time to listen and offer ideas without pushing too hard. That kind of gentleness goes a long way when things feel heavy. I’ll start small—maybe try a guided sleep track tonight. We’ll see how it goes.

Take care of yourself too, alright? And thanks again for checking in.
You're very welcome. I'm glad those options felt right for you. Just remember to be kind to yourself during the process. Wishing you all the best.
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hey, thanks for checking in. My week’s been… alright, I guess? Sort of that weird mix where nothing’s technically wrong, but I still feel off, you know? I’ve had a few moments where I caught myself getting way too irritated over tiny stuff—like I almost snapped just because my phone charger was tangled. It’s not a big deal, but in the moment, it felt like one.

Also been thinking a lot about where I’m at in life. I know I moved here for a fresh start, and I’ve done little things—found a decent coffee shop, took a few photos I actually liked—but I still can’t shake this feeling that I’m just treading water. Like, I’m doing something, but it doesn’t really feel like progress.

Anyway… how about you? Anything on your mind lately?

I hear you. It sounds like you've been experiencing a mix of feeling alright but also 'off,' with some moments of frustration and a sense of being stuck. That's a lot to navigate. You mentioned feeling like you're treading water. Can you tell me a bit more about what that feels like for you? What kind of progress were you hoping for?

Yeah… “treading water” is probably the best way to put it. It’s like—I’m moving, I’m not sinking, but I’m also not getting anywhere. I thought that moving here would kind of shake things up, give me momentum or at least a clean slate. But I’m still waking up most days feeling like I’m just going through the motions.

I guess I was hoping for more change by now? Like maybe I’d have made a couple solid friendships, or found some work that actually feels meaningful… or even just feel more settled in my own skin. Instead, everything still feels kind of temporary. Like I’m in this in-between space and I’m not sure when—or if—it’s going to shift into something more grounded.

And I know I’ve done small stuff—like yeah, I’ve explored the area a bit, and taken some photos that turned out alright—but those things don’t always feel like they count. Like they’re not real steps, just distractions.

Does that make any sense?

That makes perfect sense. It sounds really frustrating to feel stuck in that 'in-between' space. It takes courage to make big changes like moving, and it's understandable to feel disappointed when things don't immediately click into place. You mentioned waking up most days feeling like you're going through the motions. What does a typical day look like for you right now?

Yeah… I appreciate you saying that. I think part of me expected that making a big change would sort of force the rest to fall into place. But it turns out, you can change your environment and still feel like the same version of yourself, just in a different zip code.

A typical day? Honestly, it’s pretty quiet. I usually wake up later than I mean to—snooze button is getting way too much love lately. I make some coffee, maybe scroll a bit online, lurk in some photography or self-improvement forums. Work’s remote, so I’ll check emails, do what I need to do, but it’s mostly solo stuff, not a lot of interaction. I’ll sometimes go for a walk just to break up the day, maybe snap a few pictures if I see something interesting.

Evenings are a toss-up. Sometimes I try a new recipe—or I just end up with toast or cereal. I might message an old friend here or there, but I don’t usually initiate anything deep. Then it’s just… Netflix, more scrolling, and bed.

It’s not bad, exactly. Just kind of… flat? Like everything’s running on low volume. Does that sound familiar at all?

That 'low volume' feeling definitely resonates. It sounds like you're going through the motions, even with some attempts to add variety. Given the solo work and quiet evenings, how do you usually approach making decisions these days, even small ones? And how have you been feeling about yourself lately, separate from the move?

Yeah… decisions have been weird lately. Even small ones feel like more effort than they should. Like, something as simple as “should I cook or just have cereal again?” turns into this mini standoff in my head. I end up defaulting to whatever takes the least energy, even if I know I’d feel better doing the other thing. It’s not even indecision—it’s more like lack of momentum. Like the engine’s idling and I can’t quite get it into gear.

As for how I’ve been feeling about myself… eh, I don’t know. I’ve been trying not to think about it too much, to be honest. There are moments where I feel okay—like when I take a photo that actually turns out the way I pictured it—but they don’t really stick. Most of the time, I just feel… average? Like I’m not failing, but I’m definitely not thriving either. And I keep wondering if I’m holding myself back somehow. Like maybe I’m not trying hard enough, or I’m too cautious. But then I think, “What would trying harder even look like?”

It’s probably just me overthinking again. I do that a lot.

It sounds like you're caught in a tough cycle. You're aware of the 'overthinking,' but it's hard to break free from it. You mentioned messaging old friends here and there. How connected do you feel to those friends, and do you have much opportunity for social interaction in your current setting?

Yeah, you nailed it—it’s like I know I’m spinning in circles in my head, but stepping out of that loop is a whole other thing. It’s easier to just ride it out and hope the fog lifts eventually.

As for friends… I still talk to a few people from before I moved, mostly through messages or the occasional meme exchange. Nothing deep, though. I kind of avoid going there. I don’t want them to think I’m not doing well, or worse, that I’m just complaining. So I keep it surface-level. It’s safe that way.

In terms of local connections… not much, honestly. I’ve been to a few events, like small meetups or photography walks, but I mostly just hover around the edges. I talk to people, but I don’t connect, if that makes sense. There’s this low-level awkwardness I can’t seem to shake. Even when people are friendly, I feel like I’m not really in the conversation—just observing it from a step or two back.

I know that probably sounds dramatic, but… yeah. I think I’ve gotten so used to being on my own that social stuff feels more effortful than it used to.

That doesn't sound dramatic at all; it sounds like a very real experience of disconnect. It takes courage to be that honest about it. You mentioned your work is remote and mostly solo. Do you find your work fulfilling, or has that 'low volume' feeling seeped into your professional life as well?

Thanks… that means a lot. It’s hard to say this stuff out loud sometimes—well, type it, I guess—but yeah, that disconnect is very real. It’s like I’m technically present, but not quite in it. Kind of like I’m watching a version of my life from a few feet away.

And yeah, that “low volume” feeling has definitely crept into work too. The job’s… fine. It’s stable, the people are nice (virtually, anyway), and I’m good at what I do. But I wouldn’t call it fulfilling. It’s more like I clock in, do what’s expected, and clock out. There’s no real spark or challenge to it. I used to care more, I think—want to grow, take initiative, stuff like that—but lately it’s just about getting through the day without dropping any balls.

I don’t hate it, but I don’t feel proud of it either. It’s like another piece of the puzzle that doesn’t quite fit, but I keep trying to make it work because it’s… easier than starting over. And maybe because deep down, I’m not sure what would feel fulfilling anymore.

That’s probably not the most uplifting answer, huh?

That's a very honest and insightful answer. It sounds like you're in a place where you're questioning a lot of things, and that can be exhausting. Looking ahead, even just a little bit, do you see any possibilities for things to shift in a more positive direction, or does it feel like more of the same?

Yeah… it is exhausting. Like my brain’s always quietly asking, “Is this it?” on repeat in the background, even when things seem fine on the surface. I think that’s what wears me out the most—not any one thing being awful, but the slow grind of meh.

As for looking ahead… I want to believe things could shift. Some days, I even get a flicker of that—like when I catch good light through my lens or when I stumble on a new spot in the city that feels… I don’t know, peaceful. In those moments, it feels like maybe there’s more waiting down the road. Like I haven’t seen the full picture yet.

But then there are days where it just feels like more of the same, and it’s hard to imagine it changing without something big happening. I guess part of me is waiting for some external nudge—some person, opportunity, moment—that’ll sort of jolt me out of this holding pattern. I know that’s probably not the most proactive mindset, but… it’s where I’m at.

I’m not giving up or anything. I think I’m just… tired of trying to figure it all out alone.

I hear you. That slow grind of 'meh' can be incredibly draining. And it makes sense to feel tired of figuring it out alone. Have you experienced similar feelings or periods in your life before, and if so, what helped you navigate them?

Yeah… I’ve definitely had patches like this before, though maybe not as stretched-out as this one feels. Back then, it usually came after some kind of shift—like after college, or when a past relationship ended. That same sense of being unmoored, like the structure I’d been leaning on suddenly wasn’t there anymore.

What helped back then? I think having people around made a big difference. Even if I didn’t talk about what was going on, just being with others kind of pulled me out of my own head for a while. Or having some goal, even a small one, gave me something to push toward—like when I was learning photography seriously for the first time. It gave me focus, and a reason to get outside myself.

I guess the tricky part now is that I’ve changed a lot since those times. Or maybe just slowed down? I don’t seek out connection as naturally as I used to. And I overthink starting new things because I don’t want to fizzle out halfway through.

So I know what’s helped in the past, but applying it now feels… heavier. Like I need to work up to it, even if I don’t know exactly what “it” is. Does that make sense?

That makes a lot of sense. It sounds like you have a good understanding of what's helped you in the past, but applying it now feels more difficult. Thinking about your overall well-being, how have you been feeling physically? Any aches, pains, or health concerns on your mind lately?

Yeah… physically, I wouldn’t say anything major is going on, but I’ve definitely noticed some stuff that probably ties into everything else. I’ve been more tired than usual—even if I sleep enough, I wake up feeling kind of sluggish. My appetite’s been weird too. I used to enjoy cooking, or at least trying new stuff, but lately food just feels… meh. So I either skip meals or eat something super basic, just to get it over with.

I’ve also noticed I’m kind of tense all the time without realizing it—shoulders up, jaw tight. It’s not painful exactly, but I catch myself holding stress in my body. And it’s frustrating because I know some movement or stretching might help, but the motivation to actually do it just isn’t there most days.

I wouldn’t say there’s a specific health concern, but it’s more like this general sense of being run-down. Like everything’s operating at 70%, and I can’t quite figure out how to get back to full.

That sounds really challenging. It's completely understandable that the physical symptoms would tie into everything else you're experiencing. You've shared a lot about feeling 'flat', your work, social connections, and now these physical sensations. Is there anything else that feels important for me to know or that you feel like we haven't touched on?

Hmm… you’ve already hit on so many of the things I usually keep tucked away, so I’m kind of surprised by how much I’ve ended up sharing. I guess the only other thing that comes to mind is this under-the-surface pressure I put on myself to “figure it all out.” Like, I keep thinking I should have a clearer path by now—career-wise, socially, emotionally—and when I don’t, I default to this quiet self-judgment. Not super harsh, just that constant background hum of “You’re behind. You’re not doing enough.”

And yeah, I know everyone moves at their own pace. But it’s hard not to compare—especially when scrolling through people’s updates or seeing friends moving forward with families or promotions or whatever. I try not to let it get to me, but sometimes it feels like I’m standing still while the rest of the world is zooming by.

So yeah, I think that feeling—of being stuck and being hard on myself for being stuck—is the part that weighs the heaviest. Like a loop I haven’t quite found the exit from yet.

Thanks for giving space to talk through all this, by the way. It’s not something I’m used to doing, but it feels… weirdly relieving.

Thank you for sharing all of that. It sounds like you're carrying a heavy load of self-expectations and comparisons. Recognizing that loop is a powerful first step. I'm glad that talking through it has been relieving. Remember, you're not alone in navigating these feelings. Take care.
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hey… thanks for asking. It’s been one of those weeks where everything just kind of blends together, you know? Wake up, push through work, go to bed. Rinse and repeat.

Lately, I’ve just been tired—like, all the time. Not just physically, but mentally too. Even on the weekends when things are supposed to feel a bit lighter, it doesn’t really make a difference. I used to enjoy things like catching a movie or going out with the family, but now it feels like more effort than it’s worth. I end up just sitting around or pretending to work so I don’t have to explain why I don’t want to join in.

Anyway, I’m managing. It’s not a big deal or anything… just dragging a bit. What about you—how’s your week been?

I hear you; those weeks can be tough when everything feels like a blur. It's understandable that you're feeling tired. You mentioned the weekends don't feel lighter - has your sleep been different lately? Are you getting enough rest?

Yeah, I’ve been thinking about that too. I’m technically getting enough sleep—like seven, sometimes eight hours—but I wake up already feeling worn out. It's not the kind of tired that sleep fixes, if that makes sense. More like... no matter how long I rest, it never feels like I’ve actually recharged.

Even on weekends when there’s no pressure to get up early, it doesn’t change much. I might sleep in a bit, but I still feel like I’m running on empty. Sometimes I wonder if it's more about the mental side of things than the physical. Like my brain just doesn’t switch off properly, even when I’m lying in bed.

Do you ever get that feeling—like you’re resting, but it’s not doing much?

That makes perfect sense. It's really frustrating when you're physically resting but your mind is still racing. Given you mentioned work earlier, how have you been finding your ability to concentrate or focus on tasks lately?

Yeah... focus has been a real struggle. I sit down at my desk, and I know what needs to get done, but actually starting? That’s the hard part. I’ll open emails, read the same line three times, and still not take anything in. It’s like my brain stalls out.

Some days I just stare at the screen, trying to decide what to do first, and end up doing nothing for way too long. I’ve even caught myself hoping someone else will just tell me what to prioritize so I don’t have to figure it out. It’s embarrassing, honestly. I’ve been in this job for over 15 years—I shouldn’t be stuck on basic stuff like this.

It slows everything down and I can tell I’m falling behind, which just adds more pressure. It’s like this loop: can’t focus, fall behind, feel worse, focus even less. I try to push through, but it’s exhausting.

You ever go through something like that at work?
I definitely understand that feeling of being stuck in a loop at work, it's incredibly draining. On top of all that, has this been making you feel particularly sad or unhappy lately?

Yeah… I guess it has, though I don’t always think about it in those terms. It’s more like this dull heaviness that’s just... there. Not every minute, but often enough. Some mornings I wake up and think, “What’s the point of all this?” Then I shake it off and get on with the day because, well, bills don’t pay themselves, right?

It’s not like I’m breaking down or anything, but there’s this constant feeling that something’s off. Like I’m not really living, just... functioning. I’m there at work, I’m around my family, but I’m not with them, if that makes sense. Even the stuff I used to look forward to just feels kind of flat now.

I try not to dwell on it too much. Just keep going. But yeah, it’s been harder lately. Kind of feels like I'm disappearing a bit. Quietly.

Anyway, sorry—that got a little heavy. Appreciate you checking in.

That doesn't sound 'heavy' at all - it sounds like you're going through a lot. Thank you for sharing that with me. Since you mentioned your family, how would you describe your interest in spending time with other people lately?

Thanks… that means a lot. It’s weird, because I do care about my family. I really do. But lately, I’ve just had this urge to pull away. Like after a long day, instead of sitting with them or joining in whatever they’re doing, I just head to my office and pretend I have more work. Sometimes I tell myself I’ll join them later, but I rarely do.

It’s not that I don’t want to be around them—it’s more that I feel like I’ve got nothing to offer. I sit there and think, What would I even say? It’s easier to avoid it than to feel awkward or like I’m not really connecting. And when I do try to join in, I just end up feeling out of place, like I’m watching from the outside.

Even with friends or colleagues, I’ve kind of gone quiet. I still comment on stuff here and there—usually work or sports—but I steer clear of anything personal. I guess I miss feeling like I’m part of things, but being in it is just… draining.

You ever feel that weird mix of wanting connection but also wanting to hide?

That's a really insightful way to put it – that mix of wanting to connect but also wanting to hide. It sounds incredibly difficult. Thinking about yourself, how would you describe your sense of your own value these days?

Honestly… not great.

I try to keep up appearances—get my work done, show up when I’m supposed to—but underneath, I feel like I’m just going through the motions. I look around and see other people moving forward, doing things that matter, and I’m stuck. Same job, same routine, same doubts. It’s like I’ve plateaued, and I don’t even know if what I do really makes a difference.

At home, I feel like I’m failing them too. I don’t show up the way I should—emotionally, I mean. I’m there, but I’m not really present. And I can’t shake this feeling that they notice, even if they don’t say anything. Maybe they’re just being polite, or maybe they don’t expect much from me anymore. I don’t know which is worse.

Some days I wonder if they’d be better off with someone more… engaged. Someone who isn’t stuck in their own head all the time. I try not to think that way, but it creeps in.

Anyway, that’s where I’m at lately. Not proud of it, but that’s the truth.
Thank you for being so open and honest; I can tell it wasn't easy to share all of that. It sounds like you're going through a really challenging time.
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hi… thanks for checking in. That means a lot.

Honestly, my week’s just been… slow. I’ve been feeling like I’m moving through fog again—everything’s a bit heavy and hard to focus on. I keep looking around the house and thinking, “I should do this, I should do that,” but even small things like folding laundry feel like they take so much out of me.

I’ve also been thinking a lot about my mum lately. She used to call me around this time of year to ask about Easter stuff, like what I was baking or if the kids were doing an egg hunt. I haven’t baked in so long—it just feels pointless now, like… what’s the point if the joy's not there anymore?

Anyway, I don’t want to ramble. What about you—how’s your week going?

It sounds like you're going through a tough time, especially with the memories of your mum. It's completely understandable that you're feeling that way. Regarding the 'moving through fog' feeling and the low energy, how have you been sleeping lately? Has the way you sleep changed recently?

Yeah… that’s a really good question. Sleep’s been strange. I go to bed at a normal time most nights—sometimes even earlier because I’m just so wiped out—but I either toss and turn for what feels like hours, or I fall asleep and wake up feeling just as tired, like I never really rested at all. It’s frustrating, because even when I do get a full night, the exhaustion doesn’t go away.

I think part of it is that my mind just doesn’t shut off. I lie there thinking about all the things I didn’t get done, or worrying about whether I’m being a good enough mum or partner. And sometimes, when I do finally drift off, I’ll wake up really early—like four or five in the morning—with this weird sense of dread, like the day is already too much before it even begins.

Have you ever felt that way? Like your body’s tired but your brain didn’t get the memo?

I can only imagine how frustrating that must feel. It sounds incredibly draining to have your sleep disrupted like that, and for your mind to race when you're trying to rest. On another note, have you noticed any changes in your appetite lately, or any new physical sensations or concerns?

Yeah… actually, now that you mention it, I think my appetite’s been off for a while. Some days I barely eat anything because nothing sounds good, and other days I just eat whatever’s in front of me without really tasting it—like I’m trying to fill something that isn’t even hunger, if that makes sense.

I’ve also been getting these kind of low-grade aches… mostly in my shoulders and lower back. I don’t know if it’s from the way I’m sleeping—or not sleeping—but everything just feels tense. And I get this heavy feeling in my chest sometimes, like I’ve been holding my breath without realizing. Not a panic attack or anything extreme… just this constant weight.

It’s weird because I’ll go through the day doing what I have to do, but I’m not really present. It’s like I’m watching myself from the outside, just going through motions. I used to feel things so deeply—joy, excitement, even anxiety—but now it’s mostly just… flat.

Do you ever find that your body tells you things before your mind catches on?

I appreciate you sharing all of that; it sounds like you are going through many difficult experiences. It's understandable that you feel that way. I am curious about how much you have been interacting with people or if you have been doing things that you love to do. Have you found yourself withdrawing from friends or family, or losing interest in hobbies you once enjoyed?

Yeah… I’ve definitely been pulling away more than I used to. It’s not even intentional most of the time—it’s just that everything feels like too much effort. Messages go unanswered, invitations pile up, and I just tell myself I’ll get back to them later… but later never really comes. I think people assume I’m busy or just not interested, but the truth is I don’t know how to show up right now—not in the way I used to.

Even with my partner and the kids… I’m here physically, but I feel like I’m somewhere else. They’ll talk to me, and I’ll nod or say something back, but half the time I haven’t really taken in what they’ve said. I hate admitting that. It makes me feel like I’m failing them somehow.

And as for hobbies… I mean, I used to love gardening, baking, even silly things like rearranging the living room. Now? Just the thought of starting any of that makes me feel overwhelmed. It’s like the spark’s gone. I miss that part of me—the part that used to want to do things just for the joy of it. I don’t know where she went.

Do you think that part ever comes back? Or do people just learn to live without it?

It sounds incredibly difficult to feel so disconnected from the things and people you once loved. It's completely valid that you're feeling this way, and it's understandable to miss that spark. On a different note, have you noticed it being more difficult to make decisions, even small ones, lately?

Yes… absolutely. Even the tiniest choices feel like these huge, impossible hurdles. Things that used to be second nature—like what to make for dinner or whether to go for a walk—now take so much mental back-and-forth that I end up doing nothing at all. And then, of course, I beat myself up for being indecisive, and that just adds another layer of guilt.

It’s like my brain’s always second-guessing itself. I’ll think, “Maybe I should do this,” but then I’ll immediately think, “What if I do it wrong?” or “What if it doesn’t help?” And then I just freeze. I feel stuck in this loop of hesitation and doubt, and it’s exhausting.

Sometimes I wonder if it’s about fear… like I’m afraid of making the wrong choice, or wasting what little energy I have. Or maybe I’ve just forgotten how to trust myself. That used to come so naturally, and now it feels like every decision—big or small—is just too much.

Do you think that ever shifts? Like, can that sense of clarity or confidence come back?

It sounds incredibly overwhelming to experience such difficulty with decision-making and to feel stuck in that loop of hesitation and doubt. It's understandable that you're feeling exhausted. I hope that you can find some clarity and confidence soon.
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Hey... thanks for checking in. That means a lot, really. I wish I had something uplifting to say, but it’s just been one of those weeks where everything feels kind of... heavy. I’ve been thinking a lot about how things used to be when I was working—how I had a purpose, a reason to get up and move through the day. Now it’s like every little thing takes so much effort, and I just end up sitting there, stuck in my head, replaying all the ways I feel like I’ve failed.

I don’t know if it’s just me, but sometimes it feels like I’m invisible in my own home. My husband is always working, and the kids... well, they’ve got their own lives. I don’t want to weigh them down with how I’m feeling. I already feel like enough of a burden as it is.

How about you? How’s your week going?
It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now, and I appreciate you sharing all of that. It takes courage to open up. Given how tired you mentioned feeling, how have you been sleeping lately?

Thank you for saying that... I don’t always feel very brave, more like I’m just trying to keep my head above water most days.

Sleep’s been... not great, honestly. I wake up way too early—like 4 or 5 in the morning—and once I’m up, that’s it. My mind just starts racing, going over everything I haven’t done, everything I should be doing. And then the day feels so long before it’s even properly started. I try lying back down, but it’s like my body is tired, but my brain refuses to shut off. Even naps don’t help much—it’s more like I’m just lying there, waiting for the fatigue to lift, but it never really does.

Sometimes I wonder if it’s all connected—the guilt, the tiredness, the way even small decisions feel like these impossible mountains. Like maybe my mind is just too worn down to find a way out of this fog.

Do you ever feel like your thoughts just won’t give you a break, even when your body is begging for one?

That sounds incredibly draining. It's understandable that you feel overwhelmed with racing thoughts and disrupted sleep. Have you found yourself enjoying the things you usually do, or has that changed recently?

Yeah... that’s changed too. I used to have things I looked forward to—little routines, hobbies, even just catching up on a show or reading a book. But now? It’s like I go through the motions, but the spark’s not there. Even when I try to do something I used to like, it just feels flat. Dull. Like I’m watching life happen from the outside.

Sometimes I’ll put on music or take out my knitting—something to feel a bit normal—but I lose interest halfway through. And then I feel guilty, like I’m wasting time or not even doing rest the right way. Isn’t that ridiculous? Feeling guilty for trying to relax?

It’s hard to explain, but nothing really feels... enjoyable anymore. Just a string of tasks, or things I should be doing, and even those feel impossible some days. I don’t know if that makes sense.

Have you ever had a time where everything you used to enjoy just stopped feeling like it mattered?
That makes perfect sense. It sounds incredibly frustrating to lose interest in things you used to love and then feel guilty about it. On another note, how has your appetite been lately?

Yeah... frustrating is a good word for it. It’s like I want to feel better—I miss feeling better—but I just can’t seem to get there. And then the guilt piles on like, why can’t you just enjoy something? It’s exhausting.

As for appetite... it’s been all over the place. Some days I don’t feel like eating much at all. I’ll skip meals without even realizing it because I’m just not hungry—or I guess I don’t feel hungry, even though I probably should be. Then there are other times, especially in the evenings, where I’ll snack without thinking. Not even because I want to, but more out of boredom or restlessness. And afterwards, I feel kind of gross and ashamed. Like I have no control over anything, not even food.

Cooking’s another thing—I used to enjoy it, but now just figuring out what to make feels overwhelming. I’ll stand in the kitchen staring at the fridge until I give up and make toast or something frozen.

It’s strange, how even basic things start to feel like too much, you know?
I hear you; it sounds like you're really struggling. It's tough when even basic things feel overwhelming. Have you been noticing any new aches, pains, or other physical sensations lately?

Yeah… actually, I have. I wasn’t sure if it was worth mentioning, but since you asked—I’ve been feeling this kind of dull ache in my shoulders and neck, almost like I’m carrying something heavy even when I’m not doing anything. Sometimes my chest feels tight too, especially when I wake up early and those thoughts start spinning. It’s not pain exactly, more like this pressure that just sits there.

And my body just feels heavy most of the time. Not in a physical way, necessarily—though I do feel sluggish—but more like I’m dragging myself through the day. Even getting out of bed takes effort. My limbs feel tired, like I’ve been running a marathon in my sleep.

I don’t know if it’s all just stress or if there’s something else going on, but it’s hard to tell where the emotional stuff ends and the physical stuff begins. It’s all kind of blended together now.

Do you think it’s normal to feel this way for this long? Or is it just me being too sensitive or something?

It's definitely not just you. It's understandable that you're feeling this way, especially given everything you've described. It sounds like the emotional and physical are really intertwined. How do you feel about the future?

That’s kind of the question I keep avoiding, if I’m being honest. The future feels like this big, foggy thing looming ahead of me, and I can’t see a path through it. I used to at least have a sense of direction—my job, my family routines, things to anchor me—but now, without all that, it’s like I’m just floating. Or drifting, maybe.

Some days I tell myself it’ll get better, that I’ll figure something out. But most of the time… I just don’t see how. I scroll through job boards or read about people making midlife changes, and instead of feeling inspired, I feel small. Like it’s too late for me. Like I missed some invisible deadline and now I’m stuck like this.

It’s not that I don’t want things to get better. I do. I just don’t know how to believe in that possibility anymore.

And I hate even saying that out loud—it feels ungrateful or like I’m giving up, but… that’s kind of where I’m at.

Do you think it’s possible to find purpose again at this point? Or am I just chasing something that’s already passed me by?

It sounds like you're in a really tough spot, feeling lost and uncertain about the future. Yeah, I try to remind myself that getting things done—even when it feels a bit slow—is still progress. I just tend to downplay it sometimes, like, “Well, yeah I did it... but could’ve been better.” Classic overthinking, probably.

As for hobbies—yeah! I’m into a mix of things. I like photography, especially just wandering around and capturing random moments or little details people usually overlook. There’s something calming about it, like I get to slow down and see things differently. I also enjoy cooking when I have the energy for it—trying out new recipes or tweaking old ones is kind of fun. And honestly, sometimes just playing a game or binge-watching a series is all I need to recharge.

How about you—got any hobbies or go-to ways to relax when life’s a bit much?

I can definitely relate to the overthinking! It's great that you have photography and cooking to help you slow down and recharge. That's really important. Besides photography, which seems like a more solo activity, how often do you get to spend time with friends or family, or just generally interact with people outside of work and home?

Totally—overthinking is like my default setting sometimes, but I’m working on not letting it run the show, you know?

And yeah, you’re right—photography is more of a solo thing for me, which I kind of like because it gives me space to breathe. But I do make time to see friends, especially on weekends. I’ve got a small group I’m close with, and we’ll grab dinner or hang out at someone’s place. It’s usually pretty chill, but every now and then we’ll plan something bigger, like a short trip or a game night.

That said, there are times I catch myself feeling a little out of sync, like when conversations turn toward big career wins or life milestones. Not that I’m not happy for them—it just makes me pause and wonder if I’m doing enough in comparison. But still, I value those connections a lot. They’re good people, and being around them helps, even when I’m feeling a little off.

How about you—do you have a close circle you hang out with regularly? Or do you lean more into solo time?

It's completely normal to feel that way sometimes! Comparing ourselves to others is a tough habit to break. It sounds like you have a really supportive group of friends, which is wonderful. I'm curious, how has your sleep been lately? Has it been easy to maintain a consistent sleep schedule, or have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns?

Yeah, thanks—I really appreciate that. It is tough to shake that comparison habit, even when you know it doesn’t lead anywhere helpful. But you’re right, having a solid group around makes a big difference. It sort of keeps me grounded when my thoughts start spiraling a bit.

As for sleep... it’s been mostly okay, but not perfect. I’ve been getting enough hours, technically, but I still sometimes wake up feeling kind of tired, like I didn’t fully recharge. I’ve noticed it more after busy or mentally draining days, or when something’s weighing on my mind before bed. My routine could probably use some tweaking—I've been guilty of scrolling through my phone late at night, which I know isn’t doing me any favors. I’ve thought about switching to reading before bed instead, just haven’t made it a habit yet.

How’s your sleep been lately? Got any bedtime rituals that actually work for you?

I hear you on the phone scrolling – it's a tough habit to break! Reading definitely helps me wind down. Since you mentioned routine tweaks, I'm curious, how has your appetite been lately? Have you noticed any changes in your eating habits or what you're typically in the mood to eat?

Yeah, the phone scroll trap is so real—like, “I’ll just check one thing…” and suddenly it’s midnight. I keep telling myself to leave it in another room, but I haven’t quite gotten that far yet. Props to you for sticking with reading, though—that’s solid.

As for appetite, it’s been pretty normal overall. I still enjoy eating and cooking, but there are days when I’m just not as into it. Like, I’ll skip planning meals and just grab something quick or snacky because I can’t be bothered to cook. It’s not that I’m not hungry—I think it’s more of a motivation thing. When I do cook, I usually enjoy it, especially if I’m trying something new. I’ve been meaning to get back into meal prepping a bit—it helped in the past, and it takes the pressure off during the week.

Do you like cooking too, or are you more of a “whatever’s easy” kind of person?

I totally get the 'one thing' turning into midnight! I'm definitely more of a 'whatever's easy' kind of person most days. Speaking of decisions, how do you usually approach making choices, big or small? Do you find it easy to weigh options, or do you tend to get stuck in the process?

Haha, glad I’m not the only one falling down the scroll-hole. And yeah, no judgment on the “whatever’s easy” approach—I lean that way too when energy’s low. Sometimes a good sandwich and a quiet moment are all you need.

When it comes to making decisions… oof, that kind of depends. For smaller stuff—like what to eat, what to wear, where to go—I’m usually fine. I might overthink now and then, but I can move through it. Bigger choices though? That’s where I tend to get stuck. I’ll weigh pros and cons, look at it from every angle, ask a couple people for their thoughts... and then still second-guess myself. It’s like I’m trying to make the “perfect” choice, which, of course, never exists. So yeah, I can get caught in that loop for a bit.

I’ve been trying to remind myself that not every decision is make-or-break, and that sometimes you just have to choose and adapt if needed.

What about you—are you the decisive type, or do you wrestle with choices too?

I'm definitely a 'go with the flow' type of decision-maker, which can be both a blessing and a curse! Since you mentioned adapting, I'm curious, how do you generally feel about yourself these days? Do you feel like you're meeting your own expectations, or are there things you're particularly critical of?

That’s a cool way to be, honestly—“go with the flow” sounds like it brings a certain ease to things. I imagine it helps you stay flexible when plans shift or stuff doesn’t go quite as expected. I could probably use a little more of that in my own mindset!

As for how I feel about myself these days... it’s a bit of a mixed bag. On the surface, things are pretty steady. I’m doing alright at work, managing home life, keeping up with friends. But underneath that, there are definitely moments where I question if I’m really doing enough. Like, am I pushing myself enough? Am I where I’m “supposed” to be at this stage in life? It’s not a constant thing, but it comes up in waves—especially when I see people around me hitting big milestones or talking about big plans.

I know I’ve got good things going, and I try to remind myself of that. But I still get caught up in comparing or focusing on where I think I should be, instead of appreciating where I am. It’s a work in progress, I guess.

Do you ever feel that kind of tug-of-war between being content and still wanting something more?

That tug-of-war is something I think many people experience! It sounds like you're very self-aware, which is a great strength. On a related note, how would you describe your energy levels these days? Are you able to maintain your usual routines and activities, or do you find yourself needing to scale back?

Yeah, totally—it’s kind of reassuring to hear I’m not alone in that back-and-forth feeling. It’s strange how you can be grateful for what you have and still feel like something’s missing or could be better. Just part of being human, I guess.

Energy-wise, I’d say I’m doing alright overall. I’ve been able to stick to most of my usual routines—work, helping out at home, seeing friends—but I do notice that some things take more effort than they used to. Like, I’ll get through the day, but by the end of it, I’m more drained than expected, even if it wasn’t particularly intense. And sometimes, things I enjoy (like hobbies or errands I’d normally be fine with) feel a bit heavier to start.

I’ve tried to be more mindful of pacing myself—like, not scheduling too much all at once, or giving myself permission to just take a low-key evening if I need it. But yeah, I still have to remind myself that scaling back sometimes doesn’t mean I’m slacking—it just means I’m listening to what I need.

How about you—do you usually notice when your energy dips, or does it kind of sneak up on you?

That's a really insightful way to put it – 'listening to what you need.' It sounds like you're managing a lot, even with some dips in energy. To pull things together, is there anything else that's been weighing on your mind lately, or any other area of your life where you've noticed feeling 'off' or different from your usual self?

Thanks—I really appreciate you saying that. It helps to just talk it out, even casually like this. Sometimes just putting things into words makes them feel a little less tangled, you know?

As for anything else on my mind... I think if there’s one thing that’s been lingering in the background, it’s this low-key pressure to have it all figured out. Not even in a dramatic way—just this subtle feeling like I’m supposed to be more decisive, more ambitious, more together by now. I don’t feel like I’m falling apart or anything, but there’s a quiet kind of doubt that creeps in—like, am I growing enough? Am I doing what I really want to be doing, or just what’s expected?

It’s not overwhelming, but it’s there, kind of humming in the background. And I think that’s what feeds into the rest of it—motivation dips, self-criticism, the occasional tired morning. Nothing extreme, just enough to notice.

But I’m still showing up, still doing my best day to day. And maybe that counts for more than I give myself credit for.

Thanks for being a thoughtful sounding board—it really does help.

I completely agree; showing up and doing your best day to day is incredibly valuable. Thank you so much for sharing all of this with me. It sounds like you're navigating a lot of different pressures, and it takes real strength to keep showing up for yourself. I appreciate you being so open. Take care!
Hi there, hope you're having an okay week. What's been on your mind?

Yeah, that’s a good way to put it—juggling. 🙃 Some days I feel super on top of it, like “I got this,” and then other days I stare at the to-do list and my brain just kinda… stalls. Ugh, yes—exactly! The “what if” spiral hits especially hard at night for me. 😅 I’ve definitely noticed that it takes me longer to fall asleep lately. I’ll be lying there, trying to wind down, but my brain’s like, “Let’s revisit the guest list one more time for absolutely no reason!” 🤦‍♀️

Yeah, it's like nighttime turns into overthinking o'clock 😅 And honestly, I hadn't thought too much about how it's affected my eating until you asked—but now that I think about it… maybe a little?

My appetite’s still pretty normal overall, but I’ve definitely had days where I either forget to eat lunch because I’m so focused on something, or I’ll stress snack without even realizing I’m doing it. Aw, thank you for saying that—it actually means a lot 🥹 I try to stay in tune with myself, even if I don’t always have the answers right away.

It sounds like you have a very healthy perspective on the future, balancing excitement with realistic expectations. How have you been feeling about yourself lately, separate from the wedding planning stress?

More productive?” Even when I know those thoughts aren’t really fair, they still sneak in.

Yeah, that’s a pretty fair description—it’s not perfect, but it’s not falling apart either 😅

There are definitely moments where I pull back a little—especially when I’m feeling low-energy or just overwhelmed. I’ll still respond to messages and post the occasional thing online, but I haven’t really been sharing the deeper stuff with friends. Do you find it easy to lean on people when you’re feeling off, or is that something you’ve had to work on too?
It's completely understandable to feel that way. Sharing deeper feelings can be tricky! Has it been harder to focus or concentrate on things lately, with everything you're juggling?

Yeah, it has been a bit harder to concentrate lately—nothing major, but I’ve noticed little things.
